{{wiktionary|no decision}} A '''no decision''' is one of either of two complicated [[sports]] [[statistics]] scenarios: one in [[baseball]] and [[softball]], and the other in [[boxing]] and related [[combat sport]]s.
==Baseball and softball== A [[starting pitcher]] who leaves without earning either a win or a loss – that is, before either team gains or surrenders the ultimate lead – is said to have received a ''no decision'' pitching [[win–loss record (pitching)|win–loss record]], regardless of individual performance.
In [[Major League Baseball]], the record for most no decisions by a starter in a single season (dating back to at least 1908) is held by [[Bert Blyleven]], who had 20 in 1979.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/tiny/kIBhn|title=Pitching Game Finder: From 1908 to 2018, Recorded no decision, as Starter, sorted by greatest number of games in a single season matching the selected criteria|work=Baseball Reference|accessdate=July 14, 2018}}</ref> [[Tommy John]] has the all-time record of 188 career no decisions.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/tiny/wsZC2|title=Pitching Game Finder: From 1908 to 2018, Recorded no decision, as Starter, sorted by greatest number of games in all seasons matching the selected criteria |work=Baseball Reference|accessdate=July 14, 2018}}</ref>
The starting staff of the [[1918 Boston Red Sox]] picked up just 3 no decisions, the fewest of any MLB team dating back to at least 1908, while the fewest in a 162-game season is 16, by the [[1980 Oakland Athletics]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/tiny/UYdST|title=Pitching Game Finder: From 1908 to 2018, Recorded no decision, as Starter, sorted by smallest Performances matching selected criteria by a Team|work=Baseball Reference|accessdate=July 31, 2018}}</ref> The record for most no decisions by a group of starting pitchers is 66, set by the [[1993 Cleveland Indians]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/tiny/yBbHO|title=Pitching Game Finder: From 1908 to 2018, Recorded no decision, as Starter, sorted by greatest Performances matching selected criteria by a Team|work=Baseball Reference|accessdate=July 31, 2018}}</ref>
==Boxing and related combat sports== {{unsourced|section|date=October 2018}} Although uncommon these days except in [[white-collar boxing]], a ''no decision'' (ND), i.e. a tie or draw, occurs if both boxers are still standing at the bout's conclusion and there was no knockout. This may be by law, to discourage gambling; by rules to discourage injury of amateurs; or by prearrangement of the fighters, to protect titles from sudden upsets. ==References==

{{Infobox building | name = Old Gym | image = Old Gymnasium.jpg | caption = Old Gym on Vanderbilt University campus | former_names = | building_type = | architectural_style = Victorian | structural_system = | cost = | location = 2301 West End Ave. Nashville, TN | coordinates = | altitude = | start_date = 1879 | completion_date = 1880 | inauguration_date = | demolition_date = | height = | diameter = | other_dimensions = | floor_count = 3 | floor_area = 11,560 sq. ft. | main_contractor = | architect = [[Peter J. Williamson]] (assumed) | structural_engineer = | services_engineer = | civil_engineer = | other_designers = | quantity_surveyor = | awards = }} {{Infobox NRHP | name = Gymnasium, Vanderbilt University | nrhp_type = | image = | caption = | location= | coordinates = {{coord|36|8|54|N|86|48|18|W|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = | architecture = Victorian | added = February 23, 1972 | area = {{convert|1|acre}} | governing_body = | refnum = 72001233<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|version=2010a}}</ref> }} '''Old Gym''' is one of the surviving [[Victorian architecture|Victorian]] buildings that characterized the early style of the [[Vanderbilt University]] campus in [[Nashville, Tennessee]]. The Old Gym was originally a [[gym]]nasium, later served as the Fine Arts Building, and currently houses the university's admissions office.
==History== The gymnasium was completed in 1880 and featured an indoor running track and considerable gymnastic equipment. At the time, it was one of the best equipped gymnasiums in the [[southern United States]]. The exterior of the building remains fairly untouched while the interior space has been modified through the years and uses of the building.<ref name="HABS #TENN 11">{{Citation |last=Senkerith |first= Anatole, Jr. |year= 1970 |title= Historic American Building Survey: HABS #TENN 11 |publisher= US Department of the Interior, National Park Service}}</ref>
The Old Gym is on the [[National Register of Historic Places]].<ref name="nris"/> The building consisted of a foundation of Tennessee [[limestone]] with a structure of wooden [[truss]]es and walls of natural finished red brick. The [[Mansard roof]] was covered with [[slate]] shingles. Some of the original gymnastic equipment included a leaping rig, a vaulting board, [[rowing machine]], [[parallel bars]], trapeze ropes, [[Indian club]]s, [[Dumbbell|dumb bells]] and a walnut [[strandpulling|chest expander]].<ref name="HABS #TENN 11"/>
===Remodeling=== In 1962 the Old Gym was renovated and made into the Fine Arts Building by Warfield and Associates. The remodeling project included the removal of the second-floor running track and the addition of heating and cooling throughout the building.<ref>{{Citation |last= Suter|first= John, E.|year= 1961 |title= Interoffice Correspondence, May 15, 1961. Subject: Remodelling the Little Gymnasium}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Palisades Credit Union Park | nickname = | image = [[File:PCU Park Logo.png|300px]]
[[File:Provident Bank Ballpark.JPG|300px]] | builder = Holt Construction Corp, Pearl River, NY | location = Pomona, New York | coordinates = {{coord|41.170|-74.037|type:landmark_region:US-NY|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = September 10, 2010 | built = 2010–2011 | opened = June 16, 2011 | owner = Ramapo Local Development Corp | operator = Rockland Boulders | surface = Grass | construction_cost = [[US$]]38 million{{cite news |title=New Jersey Residents Have a New Baseball Option in Rockland |first=John |last=Brennan |url=http://www.northjersey.com/sports/123894684_Baseball_north_of_the_border.html |newspaper=The Record |location=Bergen County |date=June 15, 2011 |accessdate=April 28, 2012}} | architect = [[DLR Group]] | former_names = Provident Bank Park (2011-2016) | tenants = *[[Rockland Boulders]] ([[Can-Am League]]) (2011–present) *[[Dominican College (New York)|Dominican College]] ([[NCAA]])(2012-present) *[[St. Thomas Aquinas College|St. Thomas Aquinas Spartans]] ([[NCAA]]) (2012–present) *[[Nyack College]] ([[NCAA]])(2012-present) | seating_capacity = 4,506 | dimensions = Left field:{{convert|323|ft|m|abbr=on}}
Left-center:{{convert|383|ft|m|abbr=on}}
Center field:{{convert|403|ft|m|abbr=on}}
Right-center:{{convert|383|ft|m|abbr=on}}
Right field:{{convert|313|ft|m|abbr=on}} }} '''Palisades Credit Union Park''', formerly '''Provident Bank Park''' is a [[stadium]] in [[Pomona, New York]]. It is primarily used for [[baseball]] and is the home field of the [[Rockland Boulders]] of the [[Independent baseball|independent]] [[Canadian American Association of Professional Baseball|Can–Am League]]. It opened on June 16, 2011.{{cite news |title=Boulders Win Opening Game At New Stadium |first=William |last=Demarest |url=http://newcity.patch.com/articles/boulders-win-opening-game-at-new-stadium |newspaper=New City Patch |date=June 16, 2011 |accessdate=April 28, 2012}} The stadium is also home to the [[St. Thomas Aquinas College]] baseball team ([[NCAA Division II]]), who began playing all their home games at the venue in the spring of 2012.{{cite web |url=http://stacathletics.com/sports/bsb/2011-12/releases/Stadium |title=Spartans Sign Contract with State of the Art Stadium |work=St. Thomas Aquinas College |date=July 14, 2011 |accessdate=April 28, 2012}} The Spartans are the 2014 and 2017 NCAA East Region Champions. Namings were purchased by Provident Bank of New York. In 2012, the project to design and build the stadium received the Ward House Award from the Lower [[Hudson Valley]] Branch of the [[American Society of Civil Engineers]].{{cite web |title=Ward House Award |url=http://www.ascemetsection.org/branches/lower-hudson-valley-branch/awards/ward-house |work=ASCE Metropolitan Section |accessdate=November 12, 2016}} On April 25, 2016, it was announced that the naming rights had been sold to Palisades Federal Credit Union. ==Notable events== * The park hosted games 3, 4, and 5 of the 2014 Can-Am League Championship Round, featuring the Rockland Boulders and the New Jersey Jackals. It was the first time in the stadium's history that championship games were played. It did such again in 2016, this time with the Boulders hosting the Ottawa Champions. It hosted again in 2017, with the Boulders hosting the [[Quebec Capitales]]. * Field of Screams, a Halloween themed event for children that is held every October since 2015.[http://www.lohud.com/story/life/2015/10/19/field-of-screams/74046172/ Field of Screams brings scares to Provident Bank Park] ''LoHud''. Accessed September 3, 2016. * IceFest 2016 was hosted by [[St. Thomas Aquinas College]] on February 28, 2016. There was an ice rink installed inside the ball park of the stadium. The [[St. Thomas Aquinas College]] men's ice hockey team played against [[Columbia University]] that day. This event marked the first time that another sport other than baseball was played in Palisades Credit Union Park. * Other ice hockey teams that took the ice at the outdoor rink also included Nyack/Tappan Zee High School and [[Clarkstown North High School]]. ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.rocklandboulders.com/page/show/2171585-the-ball-park-a-z Palisades Credit Union Park Overview] {{Can-Am League Stadiums}} {{NewYorksportsvenues}} [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in the New York metropolitan area]] [[Category:Baseball venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Rockland County, New York]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Rockland County, New York]] [[Category:2011 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2011]] [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Ice hockey venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:College ice hockey venues in the United States]]

{{More citations needed|date=January 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox newspaper | logo = Record (newspaper).png | image = | type = Daily sports [[newspaper]] | format = [[Tabloid (newspaper format)|Tabloid]] | foundation = {{Start date and age|1949}} | owners = [[Cofina]] SGPS, S.A. | headquarters = R. Luciana Stegagno Picchio
1549-023 [[Lisbon]] | editor = Alexandre Pais | website = [http://www.record.pt/ www.record.pt] | ISSN = 3577-0015 }} '''''Record''''' is a [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] [[sport]]s [[newspaper]], founded by Manuel Dias, published in [[Lisbon]]. Although it covers most sports, [[association football|football]] is the focal point of it, and almost always is the only sport referred to on the cover. ==History and profile== ''Record'' was founded by [[Manuel Dias (athlete)|Manuel Dias]]. Dias was a newspaper vendor as well an athlete. Dias participated the [[1936 Summer Olympics]] in [[Berlin]], [[Germany]]. In 1949, Dias would enter the national lottery in Portugal and would win 40 contos. Dias would use these funds to establish the ''Record'' newspaper. The first edition of the newspaper was published on 26 of November 1949 and was sold on a weekly basis. Over the 63 years, ''Record'' have had a difficult times and gone through becoming a [[Privatization|privatizied]] company to a publicly traded one. Before the [[Carnation revolution]] ''Record'' belonged to the Banco Borges and Irmão, a bank.{{cite web|author=Helena Sousa|title=Portuguese Media: New Forms of Concentration|url=http://repositorium.sdum.uminho.pt/bitstream/1822/1620/1/hsousa_IAMCRCoreia_1994.pdf|work=University of Minho|accessdate=24 January 2015|format=Conference paper|date=1994}} Then it was nationalized following the revolution. In 1988, ''Record'' was privatized and was acquired by the company Projectos e Estudos de Imprensa (PEI), which also became the owner of the paper ''[[Diário Popular]]'' the next year.{{cite book|author1=Nelson Michaud|author2=Howard M. Hensel|title=Global Media Perspectives on the Crisis in Panama|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xOqhAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA224|accessdate=24 January 2015|date=28 April 2013|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|isbn=978-1-4094-7642-9|page=224}} The company was headed by [[Pedro Santana Lopes]], a member of the [[Social Democratic Party (Portugal)|Social Democratic Party]]. During the 1990s, ''Record'' began to be released on a daily basis from Monday to Sunday, and the paper was acquired by the [[Cofina]] media conglomerate.{{cite web|title=Portuguese Media|url=https://www.bpiequity.bpi.pt/others/PDF.aspx?id=49681|work=BPI Equity|accessdate=2 February 2015|date=5 March 2014}}{{cite news|title=Battle for Media Assets Heats Up As BPI-Cofina Raises Bid for Investec|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB9362702196164849|accessdate=11 April 2015|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=2 September 1999|location=Lisbon}} In 2005, ''Record'' created an award called the Artur Agostinho Award in memory of [[Artur Agostinho]]; the award distinguishes the person of the year in sport. ==Circulation== In 2007, ''Record'' was the third-best-selling Portuguese newspaper with a circulation of 74,000 copies.{{cite web|author=Anne Austin et. al.|title=Western Europe Market and Media Fact|url=http://conan.lib.muohio.edu/ebooks/Western_Europe_Market_MediaFact_2008/Western%20Europe%20Market%20&%20MediaFact%202008.pdf|work=ZenithOptimedia|accessdate=11 April 2015|date=2008}} The paper claimed it was the leading sport newspaper in Portugal with 62,245 copies in 2011, and was also the leading website in Portuguese sport newspapers, with 216 million page views recorded in May 2012.{{cite web|title=Record – A história|url=http://www.record.xl.pt/info/historia.aspx|work=Record}} Between September and October 2013 the paper had a circulation of 50,886 copies. ==Teams of the Year== Since 2012, ''Record'' has organised the ''Team of the Year'' award, which distinguishes the best eleven players of the calendar year of the [[Primeira Liga]].{{cite news|url=http://www.record.xl.pt/Futebol/interior_premium.aspx?content_id=796439|title=Record elege o onze de 2012|trans-title=Record elects the eleven of 2012|work=Record|language=Portuguese|date=1 January 2013|accessdate=1 January 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130101111334/http://www.record.xl.pt/Futebol/interior_premium.aspx?content_id=796439|archivedate=1 January 2013|df=dmy-all}} ===2012=== Source: {| class="wikitable" |- !Pos.!!Player!!Club |- | GK || style="width:150px;"| {{flagicon|POR}} [[Rui Patrício]] || style="width:100px;"| [[Sporting Clube de Portugal|Sporting CP]] |- | RB || {{flagicon|URU}} [[Maxi Pereira]] || [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] |- | CB || {{flagicon|BRA}} [[Maicon Pereira Roque|Maicon]] || [[FC Porto|Porto]] |- | CB || {{flagicon|ARG}} [[Ezequiel Garay]] || [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] |- | LB || {{flagicon|ARG}} [[Emiliano Insúa]] || [[Sporting Clube de Portugal|Sporting CP]] |- | DM || {{flagicon|BRA}} [[Fernando (Brazilian footballer, born 1987)|Fernando]] || [[FC Porto|Porto]] |- | CM || {{flagicon|POR}} [[João Moutinho]] || [[FC Porto|Porto]] |- | RM || {{flagicon|BRA}} [[Hulk (footballer)|Hulk]] || [[FC Porto|Porto]] |- | RM || {{flagicon|COL}} [[James Rodríguez]] || [[FC Porto|Porto]] |- | FW || {{flagicon|PAR}} [[Óscar Cardozo]] || [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] |- | FW || {{flagicon|BRA}} [[Lima (footballer)|Lima]] || [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] |} == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.record.pt/ ''Record'' online] *[http://www.vox.com.pt/ All the news from Portugal] {{Portugal newspapers}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Record}} [[Category:1948 establishments in Portugal]] [[Category:Media in Lisbon]] [[Category:Newspapers published in Portugal]] [[Category:Publications established in 1948]] [[Category:Portuguese-language newspapers]] [[Category:Sports media in Portugal]] [[Category:Sports newspapers]]

{{Refimprove|date=August 2012}} {{Infobox NFL single game | name = River City Relay | image = Jagy4.jpg | caption = [[TIAA Bank Field]] (then ALLTEL Stadium), site of the game. | visitor = [[2003 New Orleans Saints season|New Orleans Saints]] | visitor_abbr = NO | visitor_coach = [[Jim Haslett]] | visitor_record = 7–8 | home = [[2003 Jacksonville Jaguars season|Jacksonville Jaguars]] | home_abbr = JAX | home_coach = [[Jack Del Rio]] | home_record = 5–10 | visitor_qtr1 = 3 | visitor_qtr2 = 7 | visitor_qtr3 = 3 | visitor_qtr4 = 6 | visitor_qtr5 = | home_qtr1 = 0 | home_qtr2 = 17 | home_qtr3 = 3 | home_qtr4 = 0 | home_qtr5 = | date = December 21, 2003 | stadium = [[TIAA Bank Field|Alltel Stadium]] | city = [[Jacksonville, Florida]] | referee = [[Gerald Austin]]<ref>https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200312210jax.htm</ref> | attendance = | odds = | network = [[Fox NFL|Fox]] | announcers = [[Curt Menefee]] and [[Tim Green]] }} The '''River City Relay''' is a play in a [[National Football League]] (NFL) game involving the [[New Orleans Saints]] and [[Jacksonville Jaguars]] that took place on December 21, 2003, at [[Alltel Stadium]] in [[Jacksonville, Florida]]. With the Jaguars leading 20–13, the Saints used three [[lateral pass|laterals]] to score a touchdown as time expired in regulation. However, New Orleans kicker [[John Carney (American football)|John Carney]] missed the ensuing extra point that would have sent the game into overtime, and instead gave Jacksonville the 20–19 victory.
==Background== The Saints, at 7–7 entering the game, were attempting to reach the playoffs for the first time since [[2000-01 NFL playoffs|2000]]. However, they needed to win both of their final two games to have a chance at qualifying for the postseason. The Jaguars had already been eliminated from postseason contention. While the Saints led early on in the game 3–0 after a [[John Carney (American football)|John Carney]] field goal, the scoring had been mostly dominated by the Jaguars. With just seven seconds left at the end of regulation, the Jaguars had built a 20–13 lead on the Saints.
==The play== [[File: River city relay touchdown.png|thumb|150px|right|[[Jerome Pathon]] scoring the touchdown]] The Saints were on their own 25-yard line looking at second down and 10. Quarterback [[Aaron Brooks (American football)|Aaron Brooks]] passed the ball to the right side of the field to receiver [[Donté Stallworth]], who caught the pass at midfield. Stallworth then bounced off a tackle attempt by Jaguars cornerback [[Fernando Bryant]] and turned inside and broke two more tackles. The clock had already reached zero, and Stallworth pitched the ball to the 34-yard line to [[Michael Lewis (wide receiver)|Michael Lewis]], who ran the ball to the 25-yard line of Jacksonville. He then turned and pitched the ball to [[Deuce McAllister]], who ran to the Jaguars' 20-yard line. McAllister then pitched the ball to the right side of the field to [[Jerome Pathon]], who caught the ball at the 24-yard line of Jacksonville. Brooks, who had hustled all the way downfield, then laid a block on the last Jaguars defender and Pathon dove into the end-zone.
There was a lengthy delay while the officials determined that all of the ball transfers (after the pass to Stallworth) were indeed legal laterals. All the Saints needed was a [[John Carney (American football)|John Carney]] extra point to send the game into [[Overtime (sports)|overtime]] (Saints coach [[Jim Haslett]] eschewed a [[two-point conversion]] attempt to win the game immediately).
==Aftermath== Carney lined up to kick the extra point, hit a dead push, and the kick sailed wide right. The famous reaction of Saints play-by-play radio announcer [[Jim Henderson (sportscaster)|Jim Henderson]] was a horrified scream: ''"NOOOO!!! He missed the extra point wide right! Oh my God, how could he do that?"''<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kTGco82JKHo]</ref> With no time remaining on the clock, the game was over, giving the Jaguars an improbable 20–19 victory.
Earlier in the season, Coach Haslett had stated to the media that he trusted Carney so much, that he'd even stake his life on him. When reminded later that day of those same comments, Haslett stated, "Then I'd probably be dead right now. He's one of the great all-time kickers. I never would have guessed this would happen."<ref>[http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter?game_id=26551&season=2003&displayPage=tab_gamecenter&week=REG16 NFL Game Center: Post Game – New Orleans Saints at Jacksonville Jaguars – 2003 Week 16<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
With the loss, the Saints fell to 7–8 on the season and were eliminated from contention for the [[2003–04 NFL playoffs|2003 NFL playoffs]]. However, even if the Saints had won in overtime, they would have been eliminated from the playoffs, as the Dallas Cowboys won their tenth game of the season that day (9 was the highest possible number of wins the Saints could have had if they won) and the Seahawks eventually won their tenth game to gain a wild card. The Saints would, however, finish their season on a high note the next week with a 13–7 home victory over the playoff bound [[Dallas Cowboys]]. For the Jaguars, the victory would lift them to a 5–10 record. They would go on to lose the next week, 21–14, to the [[Atlanta Falcons]].
The River City Relay later went on to win the 2004 [[Best Play ESPY Award]].
{{Americanfootballbox |titlestyle= {{NFLPrimaryColor|Jacksonville Jaguars}}; {{NFLSecondaryColor|Jacksonville Jaguars}};text-align:center; |state=autocollapse |title=2003 Week 16: New Orleans Saints at Jacksonville Jaguars |date=December 21, 2003 |time=1:00 p.m. EDT |road=Saints |R1=3|R2=7|R3=3|R4=6 |home='''Jaguars''' |H1=0|H2=17|H3=3|H4=0 |stadium=[[TIAA Bank Field|Alltel Stadium]], [[Jacksonville, Florida]] |attendance=49,207 |weather=46°F, Sunny |referee=[[Gerald Austin]] |TV=[[Fox NFL|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers=[[Curt Menefee]] and [[Tim Green]] |reference= [https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200312210jax.htm Boxscore] |scoring= ;First quarter *NO [[John Carney (American football)|John Carney]] 31 yard FG ;Second quarter *JAX [[Seth Marler]] 43 yard FG *JAX [[LaBrandon Toefield]] 14 yard pass from Leftwich (Marler kick) *NO [[Boo Williams]] 2 yard pass from Brooks (Carney kick) *JAX Taylor 1 yard run (Marler kick) ;Third quarter *NO Carney 38 yard FG *JAX Marler 35 yard FG ;Fourth quarter *NO Pathon 21 pass from Brooks after laterals from [[Donté Stallworth]], [[Michael Lewis (wide receiver)|Michael Lewis]], and McAllister (kick failed) |stats= ;Top passers *NO – [[Aaron Brooks (American football)|Aaron Brooks]] – 22/38, 296 YDS, 2 TD, 0 INT *JAX – [[Byron Leftwich]] – 9/17, 131 YDS, TD, 2 INT ;Top rushers *NO – [[Deuce McAllister]] – 21 CAR, 50 YDS *JAX – [[Fred Taylor (American football)|Fred Taylor]] – 34 CAR, 194 YDS, TD ;Top receivers *NO – [[Jerome Pathon]] – 4 REC, 65 YDS, TD *JAX – Fred Taylor – 2 REC, 31 YDS }}
== Officials == *'''Referee:''' [[Gerald Austin]] (#34) *'''Umpire:''' Roy Ellison (#81) *'''Head Linesman:''' John Schleyer (#21) *'''Line Judge:''' Carl Johnson (#101) *'''Field Judge:''' Scott Edwards (#3) *'''Side Judge:''' Rick Patterson (#15) *'''Back Judge:''' Jim Howey (#37)
==See also== *[[The Play (Stanford vs. California)|The Play]], a similar last-second play in a [[1982 NCAA Division I-A football season|1982]] [[Big Game (football)|college football game]] *[[2007 Trinity vs. Millsaps football game]], a 2007 [[NCAA Division III]] game that featured a similar, but even longer, game-ending play *[[Wide Right (Buffalo Bills)]]

''SCM Craiova'' | colours = {{color box|White}} {{color box|Blue}} [[White]], [[Blue]] | owner = Craiova Municipality | chairman = Pavel Badea | club_titles = | anthem = | website = [http://www.scmcraiova.ro/ Official website] }} {{CS Universitatea Craiova sections}} '''SCM Craiova''' is a Romanian [[sports society]] from [[Craiova]], [[Romania]], founded in 2006. SCM as a subordinated of ''CS Universitatea Craiova'', mother club, administrates basketball, handball, volleyball and boxing sections while ''CS Universitatea'' administrates athletics, badminton, bridge, chess, fencing, judo, karate, table tennis and wrestling sections. Football section was originally a section of ''CS Universitatea Craiova'' but now is limited private, but still tied of this multi-sports association between SCM and CS Universitatea. == External links == *[http://www.scmcraiova.ro/ SCM Craiova website] {{ro icon}} *[http://www.csuniversitateacraiova.ro/ CS Universitatea website] {{ro icon}} {{DEFAULTSORT:SCM Craiova}} [[Category:Sports clubs established in 2006]] [[Category:Multi-sport clubs in Romania]] [[Category:University and college sports clubs]] [[Category:Sport in Craiova]] [[Category:Sports clubs in Romania|SCM Craiova]] {{Romania-sport-stub}} {{Romania-org-stub}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2013}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = TCF Bank Stadium | nickname = "The Bank" | image = [[File:TCF Bank Stadium logo.PNG|150px]]
[[File:TCF Bank Stadium - Minnesota Golden Gophers.jpg|center|260px]] | caption = | address = 420 SE 23rd Avenue | location = [[Minneapolis]], [[Minnesota]] | coordinates = {{coord|44.976|-93.225|type:landmark_region:US-MN|display=inline,title}} | pushpin_map = USA | pushpin_relief = 1 | pushpin_map_caption = Location in the United States | broke_ground = September 30, 2006 | opened = September 12, 2009 | owner = [[University of Minnesota]] | operator = University of Minnesota | surface = [[FieldTurf|FieldTurf Revolution]] | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]303,386,606{{cite web |title=Gophers Golden Moment |url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Journal/Issues/2009/09/20090921/This-Weeks-News/Gophers-Golden-Moment.aspx |work=SportsBusiness Journal |date=September 21, 2009 |accessdate=August 17, 2012}}
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|303386606|2009}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}})
$7 million Vikings upgrades | architect = [[Populous (company)|Populous]] (formerly HOKSport)
Architectural Alliance
Studio Hive | structural engineer = [[Magnusson Klemencic Associates]]{{cite web |title=TCF Bank Stadium |url=http://www.cemstone.com/tcf-bank-stadium.cfm |work=Cemstone |date=September 12, 2009 |accessdate=August 17, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120529054912/http://www.cemstone.com/tcf-bank-stadium.cfm |archive-date=May 29, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} | services engineer = R.G. Vanderweil Engineers, LLP{{cite web |title=TCF Bank Stadium |url=http://www.vanderweil.com/portfolio.php?p=sports&projects=4 |publisher=Vanderweil Engineers |accessdate=August 17, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131109184102/http://vanderweil.com/portfolio.php?p=sports&projects=4 |archivedate=November 9, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} | general_contractor = [[M.A. Mortenson Company]]{{cite press release |url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/mortenson-to-honor-24-firms-for-workforce-diversity-at-tcf-bank-stadium-and-target-field-on-november-18-70365242.html |title=Mortenson to Honor 24 Firms for Workforce Diversity-at TCF Bank Stadium and Target Field On November 18|location=Minnesota |publisher=Mortenson Construction |date=November 18, 2009 |accessdate=August 17, 2012}} | publictransit = {{rint|minnesota|green}}
at [[Stadium Village station]] | tenants = [[Minnesota Golden Gophers football|Minnesota Golden Gophers]] ([[NCAA]]) (2009–present)
[[Minnesota Vikings]] ([[National Football League|NFL]]) (2014–2015)
[[Minnesota United FC]] ([[Major League Soccer|MLS]]) (2017–2018) | seating_capacity = 50,805{{cite web |title=TCF Bank Stadium |date=September 2, 2016 |url=http://www.gophersports.com/facilities/tcf-bank-stadium.html |publisher=CBSi Advanced Media |agency=Minnesota Athletics Official Athletic Site: Football blog |accessdate=2 September 2016}} |record_attendance = 54,147 (September 3, 2015 vs. [[2015 TCU Horned Frogs football team|TCU]]) }} '''TCF Bank Stadium''' is an outdoor stadium located on the campus of the [[University of Minnesota]] in [[Minneapolis]], [[Minnesota]], United States. Opened in [[2009 Minnesota Golden Gophers football team|2009]], it is the home field of the [[Minnesota Golden Gophers football|Minnesota Golden Gophers]] of the [[Big Ten Conference]], and the temporary home of [[Minnesota United FC]] of [[Major League Soccer]].{{cite news|last=Quarstad|first=Brian|title=Minnesota United to play inaugural MLS season at new home: TCF Bank Stadium|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2016/08/19/minnesota-united-play-inaugural-mls-season-new-home-tcf-bank-stadium|publisher=Major League Soccer|date=August 19, 2016|accessdate=August 28, 2016}} The stadium also served as the temporary home of the [[Minnesota Vikings]] of the [[National Football League]] (NFL) for the 2014 and 2015 seasons during the construction of [[U.S. Bank Stadium]]. The 50,805-seat "[[horseshoe]]" style stadium cost $303.3 million to build and is designed to support future expansion to seat up to 80,000. It was the first new Big Ten football stadium constructed since [[Memorial Stadium (Indiana)|Memorial Stadium]] at [[Indiana University Bloomington|Indiana University]] opened in 1960. TCF Bank Stadium also boasts the largest home locker room in college or professional football and one of the largest video boards in the nation.{{cite web |title=Athletic Facilities: TCF Bank Stadium|publisher=University of Minnesota|url=http://www.gophersports.com/facilities/|accessdate=August 19, 2013}}{{cite web|title=TCF Bank Stadium|url=http://minnesota.cbslocal.com/guide/tcf-bank-stadium/|publisher=CBS|accessdate=January 10, 2016|date=November 9, 2010}} [[Super Bowl]] winning coach and former quarterback for the Golden Gophers [[Tony Dungy]] called the stadium "unbelievable" and [[Pro Football Hall of Fame]] wide receiver [[Cris Carter]] said that the on-campus facility "will give the University of Minnesota a chance to compete not only in the Big Ten but nationally for some of the best athletes".{{cite web |title=About Gopher Football: TCF Bank Stadium |publisher=University of Minnesota |url=http://www.gophersportsguides.com/page/show/329663-tcf-bank-stadium |accessdate=August 20, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029190106/http://www.gophersportsguides.com/page/show/329663-tcf-bank-stadium |archive-date=October 29, 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} ==History== The stadium is the third on-campus stadium and fourth stadium used for U of M football. Previous venues have been [[Northrop Field]], [[Memorial Stadium (University of Minnesota)|Memorial Stadium]], and [[Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome]]. It is the first of three [[spectator sport]]s stadiums that have been built for the major tenants of the [[Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome]] – the Gophers and two professional teams, the [[Minnesota Twins]] baseball and [[Minnesota Vikings]] football teams.{{cite news |first=Jay|last=Weiner|title=Getting Our Fix|date=November 2007|work=Minnesota Monthly|url=http://www.minnesotamonthly.com/media/Minnesota-Monthly/November-2007/Getting-our-Fix/|publisher=Greenspring Media Group|accessdate=October 21, 2007}} The Gopher football program played its first game there on September 12, 2009 against the [[Air Force Falcons football|Falcons]] of the [[United States Air Force Academy]], prevailing 20-13. This was the first football game played on-campus since November 21, 1981, the last game in Memorial Stadium. The highest-ranked [[AP Poll|AP Top 25]] team to visit was #2 [[TCU Horned Frogs football|TCU]] in 2015. [[Iowa Hawkeyes football|Iowa]] is 3-3 against Minnesota in [[Iowa–Minnesota football rivalry|rivalry games]] played at "The Bank", and one of two ranked opponents that the Gophers have defeated in the new facility (#24 Iowa in [[2010 Minnesota Golden Gophers football team|2010]] and #21 Nebraska in [[2013 Minnesota Golden Gophers football team|2013]]). At the conclusion of the 2018 season, the Gopher football team has an all-time record of 41 - 29 (0.5857) in games played at TCF Bank Stadium. ===Stadium proposal=== The push for a new on-campus stadium for Golden Gopher football began in the fall of 2000. The university cited poor revenue and lack of a college football atmosphere at the off-campus [[Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome]] as their main reasons for wanting to move back on campus.{{cite web|title=Student senate minutes|first=Rebecca|last=Hippert|url=http://www1.umn.edu/usenate/ssen/010419stu.html|publisher=University of Minnesota Student Senate|date=April 19, 2001|accessdate=July 8, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090116165539/http://www1.umn.edu/usenate/ssen/010419stu.html|archivedate=January 16, 2009|df=mdy-all}}{{cite news |title=U of M May Go It Alone in Stadium Chase|first=Tim|last=Pugmire|url=http://news.minnesota.publicradio.org/features/200212/13_pugmiret_stadium/|work=[[Minnesota Public Radio]]|date=December 13, 2002|accessdate=July 8, 2007}} A plan for a joint [[Minnesota Vikings]]/University of Minnesota football stadium was proposed in 2002, but differences over how the stadium would be designed and managed, as well as state budget constraints, led to the plan's failure.{{cite news |title=Committee Kills Vikings Stadium Plan|first=Tom|last=Scheck|url=http://news.minnesota.publicradio.org/features/200202/18_khoom_stadiums/index.shtml|work=[[Minnesota Public Radio]]|date=February 18, 2002|accessdate=July 8, 2007}} In September 2003 a highly publicized attempt was made by [[T. Denny Sanford]] to be the lead donor for the project, but in early 2004 the plan fell through when the two parties were unable to come to an agreement on the financial terms.{{cite news |title=Officials: Stadium Plan Must Progress|last=Tibbetts|first=Than|url=http://www.mndaily.com/articles/2004/10/19/10766|newspaper=[[Minnesota Daily]]|date=October 19, 2004|accessdate=July 8, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080211104334/http://www.mndaily.com/articles/2004/10/19/10766|archivedate=February 11, 2008}} The university unveiled preliminary stadium drawings and a general plan to seek state money and donations in December 2003. On March 24, 2005, the university and TCF Bank announced a deal that would have the bank contribute $35 million towards the project which would give them naming rights.{{cite web|title=TCF Financial Corporation Gives $35 million |url=http://www1.umn.edu/umnnews/Feature_Stories/Gophers_new_TCF_Bank_Stadium.html |publisher=University of Minnesota |date=March 24, 2005 |accessdate=January 10, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060113215828/http://www1.umn.edu/umnnews/Feature_Stories/Gophers_new_TCF_Bank_Stadium.html |archivedate=January 13, 2006 |df= }} The deal was given an expiration date of December 31, 2005; time enough for the [[Minnesota Legislature]] to provide the bulk of funding needed to make the project a reality.{{cite web|title=Stadium Sponsorship Agreement With TCF Extended|url=http://www1.umn.edu/umnnews/Feature_Stories/Stadium_sponsorship_agreement_with_TCF_extended.html|publisher=University of Minnesota|date=December 28, 2005|accessdate=December 28, 2005|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060505025459/http://www1.umn.edu/umnnews/Feature_Stories/Stadium_sponsorship_agreement_with_TCF_extended.html|archive-date=May 5, 2006|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} During the remainder of 2005 the university concentrated on drafting a stadium proposal that would draw the support of state politicians. The final plan proposed that the state of Minnesota would contribute 40% of the stadium cost while the university would raise the remaining 60% on its own. Portions of that 60% were to be funded by the TCF naming rights, while the remainder would come from a $50 per semester student fee, private donations, the sale of 2,840 acres (11.5 km²) of university land in rural [[Dakota County, Minnesota|Dakota County]] back to the state, and game day parking revenue. Even though the university proposal drew widespread legislative support, the stadium effort suffered a setback when the 2005 legislative session ended before the stadium [[Bill (proposed law)|bill]] could be heard.{{cite web |title=At the Legislature|publisher=University of Minnesota via Internet Archive|url=http://www1.umn.edu/stadium/legislature.html|accessdate=December 21, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070109075654/http://www1.umn.edu/stadium/legislature.html|archivedate=January 9, 2007}} Late in 2005 when it became evident that this would happen, the university and TCF Bank announced that it had extended the naming rights deal to June 30, 2006. [[File:TCF Bank Stadium opener.jpg|thumb|200px|Stadium opener vs. [[2009 Air Force Falcons football team|Air Force]]
on September 12, 2009]] Despite the 2005 session having ended with the bill not coming to a vote, the stadium effort did not lose momentum in the legislature and was introduced quickly in the 2006 session. On April 6, 2006, the [[Minnesota House of Representatives]] passed the stadium bill on a 103–30 vote.{{cite web|title=Unofficial Recorded Roll Call Floor Vote for H.F. NO. 263|publisher=Minnesota House of Representatives|date=April 6, 2006|url=http://www.house.leg.state.mn.us/votes/votes.asp?ls_year=84&session_number=0&year=2005&id=564|accessdate=December 21, 2006|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090112010239/http://www.house.leg.state.mn.us/votes/votes.asp?ls_year=84&session_number=0&year=2005&id=564|archivedate=January 12, 2009|df=mdy-all}} The house bill was nearly identical to what the university was proposing and had full university support.{{cite news |title=House Panel Adds Its Support to U Stadium Funding Plan|first=Anthony|last=Lonetree|url=http://blog.lib.umn.edu/stadium/stadium/2006/03/|newspaper=[[Star Tribune]]|location=Minneapolis|date=March 29, 2006|accessdate=July 8, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070614164223/http://blog.lib.umn.edu/stadium/stadium/2006/03/|archivedate=June 14, 2007}} However, on May 9, 2006, the [[Minnesota Senate]] passed a radically different version of the bill on a 34–32 vote.{{cite journal |title=Permanent Journals of the 2006 Regular Session|journal=Journal of the Senate|volume=2005 - 2006|issue=Eighty–Fourth Legislature|page=5332|publisher=Minnesota State Senate|date=May 9, 2006|url=http://www.senate.leg.state.mn.us/journals/2005-2006/20060509103.pdf|id=Legislative Day 103|accessdate=December 21, 2006|format=PDF}} The Senate version would have removed the TCF naming rights deal, the student fees, and the purchase of the university owned land. The proposed funding that was removed was to be replaced with a statewide tax on [[sports memorabilia]]. It also would have required the stadium to be named Veterans Memorial Stadium (similar to the previous on-campus football stadium Memorial Stadium, which was last used in 1981 and demolished in 1992).{{cite news |title=Senate Passes Stadium Bills for Twins, Gophers, and Vikings|first=Tom|last=Sheck|work=[[Minnesota Public Radio]]|date=May 9, 2006|url=http://minnesota.publicradio.org/display/web/2006/05/09/gopherstadium/|accessdate=July 8, 2007}} Governor [[Tim Pawlenty]] stated he supported the House version.{{cite news |title=Gophers Stadium Plan Passes Senate|first=Mike|last=Kaszuba|url=http://blog.lib.umn.edu/stadium/stadium/2006/05/|newspaper=[[Star Tribune]]|location=Minneapolis|date=May 9, 2006|accessdate=May 21, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070316083841/http://blog.lib.umn.edu/stadium/stadium/2006/05/|archivedate=March 16, 2007}} He signed the bill in May 2006 at the University of Minnesota [[McNamara Alumni Center]].{{cite web |title=Stadium Bill Signed at McNamara|url=http://www.alumni.umn.edu/Stadium_Signing.html|date=May 25, 2006|publisher=Regents of the University of Minnesota via University of Minnesota Alumni Association|accessdate=December 11, 2007}} ===Legislative approval 2006=== Even though the differences between the [[Minnesota House of Representatives|House]] and [[Minnesota Senate|Senate]] bills were major, the details were ironed out and approved on May 19, in a House–Senate [[conference committee]]. The naming rights and land sale remained in the bill, as did a scaled down $25 per year student fee. The tax on sports memorabilia as well as the Veterans Memorial Stadium name were voted out. The committee also voted to increase the state contribution to the project to compensate for the smaller student fees.{{cite news |title=Stadium Bill Highlights|first=Tim|last=Pugmire|url=http://blog.lib.umn.edu/stadium/stadium/2006/05/|work=[[Minnesota Public Radio]]|date=May 20, 2006|accessdate=July 8, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070614164230/http://blog.lib.umn.edu/stadium/stadium/2006/05/|archivedate=June 14, 2007}} The compromise bill was then approved by both the full house and senate on May 20, and was signed by Governor Tim Pawlenty on May 24.{{cite web|title=Unofficial Recorded Roll Call Floor Vote for S.F. NO. 2460|publisher=Minnesota State House of Representatives|date=May 20, 2006|url=http://www.house.leg.state.mn.us/votes/votes.asp?ls_year=84&session_number=0&year=2005&id=839|accessdate=December 21, 2006|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090112010930/http://www.house.leg.state.mn.us/votes/votes.asp?ls_year=84&session_number=0&year=2005&id=839|archivedate=January 12, 2009|df=mdy-all}}{{cite journal |title=Permanent Journals of the 2006 Regular Session|journal=Journal of the Senate|volume=2005 - 2006|issue=Eighty–Fourth Legislature|pages=5780–5787|publisher=Minnesota State Senate|date=May 20, 2006|url=http://www.senate.leg.state.mn.us/journals/2005-2006/20060509103.pdf|id=Legislative Day 111|accessdate=December 21, 2006|format=PDF}}{{cite news |title=Pawlenty Signs One Stadium Bill; One to Go|first=Tim|last=Pugmire|url=http://minnesota.publicradio.org/display/web/2006/05/24/gophersstadium/|work=[[Minnesota Public Radio]]|date=May 24, 2006|accessdate=December 21, 2006}} ===Construction=== {{double image|right|2008-0511-TCFStadium-001.jpg|218|2009-05-07 TCF Bank Stadium.jpg|200|Under construction, May 2008|One year later, May 2009}} On June 8, 2006, the university announced that it had selected [[Populous (company)|Populous]] to design the stadium.{{cite news|title=Kansas City Firm Chosen to Design Gophers' New Stadium|first=Mike|last=Kazuba|url=http://www.startribune.com/512/story/480963.html|newspaper=[[Star Tribune]]|location=Minneapolis|date=June 8, 2006|accessdate=June 8, 2006|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060615052110/http://www.startribune.com/512/story/480963.html|archivedate=June 15, 2006|df=mdy-all}} [[Populous (company)|Populous]] (then HOK Sport) was one of the three finalists, along with [[HNTB| HNTB Architects]] and Crawford Architects, that made presentations to the university on May 24, 2006. The local firm that worked on the project was Minneapolis-based ''Architectural Alliance'', and [[M.A. Mortenson Company]] was the general contractor.{{cite web |title=Back to Campus|publisher=University of Minnesota via Internet Archive|url=http://www1.umn.edu/stadium/index.php|accessdate=December 21, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071227043330/http://www1.umn.edu/stadium/index.php|archivedate=December 27, 2007}}{{cite web|title=University selects M.A. Mortenson Company as general contractor|publisher=University of Minnesota|date=February 15, 2007|url=http://www.gophersports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=38605&SPID=3280&DB_OEM_ID=8400&ATCLID=798968|accessdate=February 20, 2007}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Schematic designs of the stadium were presented to the public on January 3, 2007.{{cite web|title=Designs for TCF Bank Stadium Released to the Public|publisher=University of Minnesota|date=January 3, 2007|url=http://www.gophersports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=8400&ATCLID=736453|accessdate=May 21, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090116095453/http://www.gophersports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=8400&ATCLID=736453|archivedate=January 16, 2009|df=mdy-all}} Infrastructure work at the stadium site began in late June 2006, and a [[Groundbreaking|ceremonial groundbreaking]] took place at the stadium site on September 30, 2006. The beginning of construction on the stadium itself along with the unveiling of the stadium's [[logo]] took place on July 11, 2007.{{cite web|title=TCF Bank Stadium logo unveiled to signal start of Gopher football stadium construction|publisher=University of Minnesota|url=http://www1.umn.edu/umnnews/news_details.php?release=070706_3399&page=UMNN|date=July 6, 2007|accessdate=July 6, 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509011859/http://www1.umn.edu/umnnews/news_details.php?release=070706_3399&page=UMNN|archive-date=May 9, 2008|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web |title=TCF Bank Stadium Construction PHASE 3|publisher=University of Minnesota via Internet Archive|url=http://www1.umn.edu/stadium/phase3.html|accessdate=December 21, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070118193153/http://www1.umn.edu/stadium/phase3.html|archivedate=January 18, 2007}} Site preparation and [[Foundation (architecture)|foundation]] work continued through the summer and fall of 2007. More than 8,800 tons of steel that make up the stadium's skeleton was put in place between January 28, 2007 – June 28, 2008.{{cite web|title=Steel Set to Rise at TCF Bank Stadium|publisher=University of Minnesota|date=January 25, 2008|url=http://www.gophersports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=8400&ATCLID=1374528|accessdate=January 27, 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090116083230/http://www.gophersports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=8400&ATCLID=1374528|archivedate=January 16, 2009|df=mdy-all}}{{cite news|title=U of M to Finish Stadium's Steel Structure Friday|agency=Associated Press|url=http://www.startribune.com/sports/21985884.html?location_refer=Error|newspaper=[[Star Tribune]]|location=Minneapolis|date=June 27, 2008|accessdate=July 21, 2008}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Location== The stadium is located on the northeast side of the Minneapolis campus, near the site of the former Memorial Stadium, across from [[Williams Arena]]. The site was previously the Huron Boulevard Parking Complex, where the university's four largest parking lots were located.{{cite web|title=Stadium Location |publisher=University of Minnesota via Internet Archive |date=July 18, 2006 |url=http://www.umn.edu/stadium/location.html# |accessdate=December 21, 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060502063337/http://www1.umn.edu/stadium/location.html |archivedate=May 2, 2006 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The address is 2009 University Ave S.E.{{cite web|title=TCF Bank Stadium Logo Unveiling Signals Start of Construction Phase|publisher=University of Minnesota|date=July 11, 2007|url=http://www.gophersports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=8400&ATCLID=1087853|accessdate=July 11, 2007}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The stadium is part of a {{convert|75|acre|sing=on}} expansion of the Twin Cities campus, the largest since the [[University of Minnesota#West Bank|West Bank]] was built in the 1960s. Current plans for the area call for the construction of as many as ten new academic buildings by 2015. The [[METRO (Minnesota)|METRO]] [[Green Line (Minnesota)|Green Line]] [[light rail]] runs near the stadium, with a [[Stadium Village (Metro Transit station)|station]] in [[Stadium Village, Minneapolis|Stadium Village]] serving the facility. Construction of the Green Line began in 2010 and opened June 14, 2014.{{cite web|title=Central Corridor Light-Rail Transit Factsheet |publisher=Metropolitan Council |date=December 2006 |url=http://metrocouncil.org/about/facts/CentralCorridorFacts.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=December 21, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070615050209/http://metrocouncil.org/about/facts/CentralCorridorFacts.pdf |archivedate=June 15, 2007 }} The two other major Twin Cities stadiums are located along this line, within a short distance and travel time on the [[Light rail]] line. An [[Environmental Impact Assessment|environmental impact assessment]] of the stadium site was conducted by the university between December 2004 and March 2006 at a cost of $1.5 million. The results were approved by the Board of Regents on March 27, 2006.{{cite web |title=Environmental Review Process|publisher=University of Minnesota via Internet Archive|url=http://www1.umn.edu/stadium/environmental_review.html|accessdate=June 19, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070807144513/http://www1.umn.edu/stadium/environmental_review.html|archivedate=August 7, 2007}} ==Design== [[File:TCF Bank Stadium 2.JPG|thumb|right|Visitor side from the main light bank on top of the press gallery]] The stadium is a horseshoe-style stadium which organizers said would have a "traditional collegiate look and feel". On December 7, 2006, the university announced that the stadium's field would be laid out in an unorthodox east-west configuration, with the open west end of the stadium facing campus. This layout, similar to that of Memorial Stadium, provides a view of downtown Minneapolis.{{cite news|title=Gophers' Stadium Costs Expected to Rise|first=Mary Jane|last=Smetanka|url=http://www.startribune.com/512/story/861532.html|newspaper=[[Star Tribune]]|location=Minneapolis|date=December 7, 2006|accessdate=December 7, 2006|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061210003422/http://www.startribune.com/512/story/861532.html|archivedate=December 10, 2006|df=mdy-all}} On September 18, 2009, the University of Minnesota announced that the stadium was awarded [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design|LEED]] Silver Certification, the first college or professional football stadium to achieve LEED certification.{{cite web |title=TCF Bank Stadium achieves LEED Certification|url=http://www.gophersports.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/091809aad.html|publisher=University of Minnesota|accessdate=January 8, 2017}} ===General features and football facilities=== The centerpiece of the stadium is the massive scoreboard, designed and built by [[Daktronics]] at a cost of $9 million. At {{convert|48|x|108|ft|1}}, the HD-X [[light-emitting diode]] (LED) video scoreboard is currently the largest in college football-only stadiums,{{cite web|title=TCF Bank Stadium: About the Stadium: Design|url=http://stadium.gophersports.com/about_design.html|publisher=University of Minnesota|accessdate=June 18, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090831045526/http://stadium.gophersports.com/about_design.html|archivedate=August 31, 2009|df=mdy-all}} and was the third largest at the time of construction.Schuster, Ryan - [https://archive.is/20140119133607/http://www.prairiebizmag.com/event/article/id/9681/ Daktronics a major league player in sports arena]. Prairie Business Magazine, July 1, 2009 The playing surface is [[FieldTurf]], an infilled [[artificial turf]], and the brick wall surrounding the playing field was made possible by an alumni donation of $500,000.{{cite web |title=Minnesota Selects FieldTurf for new TCF Bank Stadium|publisher=FieldTurf|year=2009|url=http://www.fieldturf.com/en/artificial-turf/artificial-turf-news/minnesota-selects-fieldturf-for-new-tcf-bank-stadium|accessdate=August 20, 2013}}{{cite web |title=MN businesses contributed $91M to stadium, then they built it|publisher=Minneapolis St. Paul Business Journal|date=Aug 23, 2009|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/twincities/stories/2009/08/24/smallb3.html?page=all|accessdate=August 20, 2013}} Located on the stadium ground level is the [[Murray Warmath]] Locker Room, named in honor of the Gophers' national championship winning coach from 1954 to 1971. It is the largest home locker room in college or professional football, and features a block “M” lighting fixture and 120 custom-built [[Prunus|cherry-wood]] lockers.{{cite web|title=Murray Warmath Locker Room & Team Areas |publisher=University of Minnesota |url=http://www.gophersportsguides.com/page/show/329664-the-largest-locker-room-in-football |accessdate=August 20, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029200142/http://www.gophersportsguides.com/page/show/329664-the-largest-locker-room-in-football |archivedate=October 29, 2013 }}{{Primary source inline|date=January 2016}} Adjacent to the Murray Warmath Locker Room are other team areas including a fully equipped training room, therapy room, medical exam rooms, an equipment room, custom coaches’ offices and locker rooms, a home media room, private recruiting room, and a training table for dining and nutrition. After a tour of the complex, Pro Bowl wide receiver [[Larry Fitzgerald]] remarked that, "This has got to be the best locker room in the Big Ten." ===Stadium aesthetics=== [[File:Winter at TCF Bank Stadium - county names carved in stone on building exterior.jpg|thumb|County names carved in stone]] To recognize that the venue was paid for with taxes statewide and to pay tribute to the support of Minnesota citizens, the names of the [[List of counties in Minnesota|state's 87 counties]] are cast in stone around the perimeter of the first level. Each is engraved in a piece of cast stone that is {{convert|16|x|5.3|ft}} and weighs {{convert|6500|lb}}.{{cite web |title=U of M TCF Bank Stadium unveils first county signs|publisher=University of Minnesota|date=May 27, 2008|url=http://www1.umn.edu/news/news-releases/2008/UR_RELEASE_MIG_4803.html|accessdate=August 19, 2013}} These panels are contained within the reminiscent Memorial Wall, which forms the external surface of the stadium building. This brick façade perimeter wall with arched portals reflects the heritage of Memorial Stadium's exterior, and a 360° colonnade provides a year-round walkway around the stadium.{{cite web |title=Bringing History Back: University of Minnesota TCF Bank Stadium|publisher=Populous|year=2009|url=http://populous.com/project/um-tcf-bank-stadium/|accessdate=August 19, 2013}} Displayed on the façade of the stadium's upper deck are panels commemorating the 7 national championships and 18 Big Ten Conference championships won by Minnesota in football, as well as ones distinguishing the five players whose numbers have been retired by the program.{{cite news |title=Gophers Retire Bobby Bell's No. 78 Jersey|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=October 2, 2010|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/college/football/2010-10-02-4185631916_x.htm|accessdate=August 20, 2013}} The Minnesota Tribal Nations Plaza encompasses the main western entrance to the stadium and is named in honor of the 11 [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] nations in Minnesota, featuring eleven {{convert|18|ft|sing=on}}-tall sky markers: one for each nation.{{cite web |title=Tribal Nations Plaza Dedicated at New Stadium|publisher=University of Minnesota|year=2007|url=http://www.gophersports.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/081709aab.html|accessdate=August 20, 2013}} The stadium also incorporates the Veterans Tribute, a memorial dedicated to Minnesota [[veteran]]s, located in the open end of the horseshoe near the main plaza.{{cite news |first=Liz|last=Riggs|title=Appreciation day honors U veterans|url=http://www.mndaily.com/articles/2007/11/15/72164546|newspaper=[[Minnesota Daily]]|date=November 15, 2006|accessdate=December 8, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071116065752/http://www.mndaily.com/articles/2007/11/15/72164546|archivedate=November 16, 2007}}{{cite web |title=U to dedicate Veterans Tribute|publisher=University of Minnesota|date=September 9, 2009|url=http://www1.umn.edu/news/features/2009/UR_CONTENT_129577.html|accessdate=August 20, 2013}} ===Seating and amenities=== [[File:Winter at TCF Bank Stadium - panorama.jpg|thumb|Panorama of seating]] The first phase of the construction includes approximately 50,805 seats, with the design able to support future expansion of up to 80,000 seats. The 10,000-seat student section is located in the eastern end of the stadium, and the area reserved for the [[University of Minnesota Marching Band]] is partitioned from it, situated directly behind the eastern end zone and framed by a backdrop labeled ''Pride of Minnesota.''{{cite news|title=TCF Bank Stadium: A New Era for Gophers Football|url=http://www.startribune.com/newsgraphics/27287664.html|newspaper=[[Star Tribune]]|location=Minneapolis|date=February 9, 2011|accessdate=August 19, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029193036/http://www.startribune.com/newsgraphics/27287664.html|archivedate=October 29, 2013|df=mdy-all}} There are approximately 20,000 seats with permanent chairbacks in the stadium, located between the goal lines in both the upper and lower decks, but all remaining locations have aluminum bench seating with no backs.{{cite web |title=TCF Bank Stadium Quick Facts|publisher=University of Minnesota|year=2013|url=http://www.gophersports.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/030709aaa.html|accessdate=August 20, 2013}} The stadium also features 1,000 handicap accessible and companion seats, and accessible seating is located throughout the stadium, including in the first row of the first level, the last row of the first level, and the last row of the second level.{{cite web|title=TCF Bank Stadium|publisher=University of Minnesota|url=http://www.gophersportsguides.com/page/show/329663-tcf-bank-stadium|accessdate=August 19, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029190106/http://www.gophersportsguides.com/page/show/329663-tcf-bank-stadium|archive-date=October 29, 2013|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} Premium seating includes 37 private suites, 250 indoor club seats, 1,250 outdoor club seats, and 50 [[Box (theatre)|loge]] boxes, along with access to the exclusive {{convert|20,000|sqft|sing=on}} climate-controlled DQ Club Room, which offers luxurious amenities to premium-seat ticket holders.{{cite web |title=Stadium Features|publisher=University of Minnesota via Internet Archive|url=http://www1.umn.edu/stadium/features.html|accessdate=May 21, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071025005557/http://www1.umn.edu/stadium/features.html|archivedate=October 25, 2007}}{{cite web|title=TCF Bank Stadium Premium Seating - DQ Club Room|publisher=University of Minnesota|year=2013|url=http://www.gophersports.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/051608aab.html|accessdate=August 19, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029190146/http://www.gophersports.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/051608aab.html|archivedate=October 29, 2013|df=mdy-all}} The main concourse is on the second level and wraps around the entire stadium, open to the field of play. Concessions and many of the venue's 113 restrooms are located here. Located in the southwest corner of the stadium is Goldy's Locker Room, the team store, which spans two floors. The T. Denny Sanford Athletics Hall of Fame was opened in fall of 2010, positioned in the southwest end of the stadium next to Goldy's Locker Room.{{cite web |title=T. Denny Sanford Athletics Hall of Fame|publisher=University of Minnesota|url=http://www.gophersports.com/trads/hall-fame.html|accessdate=August 19, 2013}} The more than {{convert|5,000|sqft|sing=on}} Hall of Fame is not football specific, rather encompassing all 25 of the University of Minnesota's athletic programs through dramatic imagery, artifacts, and interactive kiosks. Visitors to the Hall of Fame hear a soundscape with some of the great radio calls from Minnesota's play-by-play voices. The space also honors the members of the 'M' Club Hall of Fame with a wall complete with plaques for each inductee. The Hall of Fame housed the [[Iowa–Minnesota football rivalry|Floyd of Rosedale]] trophy after a win over [[2010 Iowa Hawkeyes football team|Iowa]] in [[2010 Minnesota Golden Gophers football team|2010]]. The media area is a three-tiered press box with 10 network TV camera positions and seating for 160 members of the media.{{cite web|title=TCF Bank Stadium: Media Areas|publisher=University of Minnesota|url=http://www.gophersportsguides.com/page/show/329667-media-areas|accessdate=August 20, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131030012741/http://www.gophersportsguides.com/page/show/329667-media-areas|archive-date=October 30, 2013|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} ===Expansion=== The stadium was designed to be capable of supporting future seating expansion to 80,000. The 30,000 seats would be added above the second deck of the stadium from the end of the press boxes across to the northwest end of the venue, wrapping around the remainder of the horseshoe. The auxiliary video display currently adjacent to the easternmost section of the media areas would likely be relocated to atop the new third deck. The University of Minnesota could add all 30,000 seats in a single addition or in increments of 10,000 seats, meeting demand as it is needed (although the duplicated costs of such a plan make it unlikely). If expansion is ever undertaken, it can be completed in about 9 months so that there would be minimal interruption of a football season.{{cite web |title=TCF Bank Stadium expansion|publisher=GopherHole.com|date=September 8, 2009|url=http://www.forums.gopherhole.com/boards/showthread.php?7761-TCF-Bank-Stadium-expansion|accessdate=August 19, 2013}} ==2014 changes== For the [[2014 NFL season|2014]] and [[2015 NFL season|2015]] seasons, the [[Minnesota Vikings]] of the [[National Football League]] (NFL) used TCF Bank Stadium as their home venue while their new venue, [[U.S. Bank Stadium]], was under construction at the site of the [[Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome|Metrodome]]. To help accommodate the Vikings, TCF Bank Stadium underwent several changes, including a new playing surface with heating coils, increased storage space throughout the stadium, and concession upgrades.{{cite web |url=http://www.vikings.com/news/article-1/Northern-Home-Vikings-Choose-North-Sideline-at-Gophers-Stadium/5ecf260b-581b-4adc-ba4a-4c41e7c99d55 |title=Northern Home: Vikings Choose North Sideline at Gophers Stadium |publisher=Vikings.com |first=Mike |last=Wobschall |date=27 June 2014 |accessdate=18 July 2014}} In addition, temporary seats were installed that increased the stadium's capacity to 52,525.{{cite news |title=TCF Bank Stadium changes |url=http://www.startribune.com/sports/vikings/270420741.html |newspaper=[[Star Tribune]] |date=August 8, 2014 |accessdate=January 4, 2015}} These accommodations were expected to cost about $7 million - an amount attributed to the overall construction cost of the new stadium{{cite web |url=http://thevikingage.com/2014/07/17/new-bleacher-construction-appears-begun-tcf-bank-stadium-photo/ |title=New Bleacher Construction Appears to Have Begun at TCF Bank Stadium |publisher=Fansided.com |first=Dan |last=Zinski |date=July 17, 2014 |accessdate=July 18, 2014}} ==Funding== The stadium's cost totals $288.5 million, of which the university will pay 52% and the state of Minnesota the remaining 48%. Including interest the state's cost is about $10 million per year or about $1.7 million per game for 25 years.{{cite news |title=University of Minnesota Gophers football stadium|url=http://minnesota.publicradio.org/projects/ongoing/votetracker/issue_view.php?id=46 |work=[[Minnesota Public Radio]]|date=May 24, 2006 |accessdate=October 21, 2007}} About $50 million of the state's portion goes to the purchase of 2,840 acres (11.5 km²) of undeveloped university land, part of the Rosemount Research Center in [[Dakota County, Minnesota|Dakota County]], over 25 years by the state of Minnesota who will assume responsibility for risks if the site requires environmental cleanup.{{cite journal|first=Britt|last=Robson|title=Gopher Broke|url=http://citypages.com/databank/27/1331/article14406.asp|journal=City Pages|publisher=Village Voice Media|volume=27|issue=1331|date=June 7, 2006|accessdate=October 21, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081204165829/http://citypages.com/databank/27/1331/article14406.asp|archivedate=December 4, 2008|df=mdy-all}}The U of M Rosemount Research Center is an EPA Superfund site that required more review and "Institutional Controls" as of June 2007. {{cite web |title=Third Five-Year Report for University of Minnesota Rosemount Research Center Site: Executive Summary|url=http://www.epa.gov/R5Super/fiveyear/reviews_pdf/minnesota/university_of_minnesota_rosemount_mn_272773.pdf|format=PDF|date=June 15, 2007|page=5|publisher=United States Environmental Protection Agency Region 5|accessdate=October 21, 2007}} The university retains its right to use the land for its "research, education and engagement mission" in perpetuity.{{cite web |author=Office of the Vice President, Statewide Strategic Resource Development, University of Minnesota|title=Creating the Vision, The Future of UMore Park|url=http://www.umorepark.umn.edu/sites/c9e0e563-70e4-43e4-8a5e-b620e3ae848e/uploads/UMoreVisionReportFINAL10-26-06-4.pdf|format=PDF|page=5|publisher=Regents of the University of Minnesota|date=October 16, 2006|accessdate=October 21, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070628045555/http://www.umorepark.umn.edu/sites/c9e0e563-70e4-43e4-8a5e-b620e3ae848e/uploads/UMoreVisionReportFINAL10-26-06-4.pdf|archivedate=June 28, 2007}} The [[University of Minnesota|university]]'s share was $111 million or 52%.{{cite web |title=TCF Bank Stadium Financing|publisher=University of Minnesota via Internet Archive|url=http://www1.umn.edu/stadium/financing.html|accessdate=July 8, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071025060117/http://www1.umn.edu/stadium/financing.html|archivedate=October 25, 2007}} [[TCF Financial Corporation]] of [[Wayzata, Minnesota]] is contributing $35 million over 25 years in exchange for the ''[[TCF Bank]]'' [[naming rights]] and other agreements. The university projected earnings of $2.5 million per year or $96 million over the life of agreements with TCF that will include marketing debit cards to alumni and ticketholders.{{cite news |title=TCF Perks Go Beyond Stadium's Name at U|first=Mike|last=Kaszuba|url=http://goallineclub.com/index.php?page=news_item&id=67|newspaper=[[Star Tribune]]|location=Minneapolis|date=July 6, 2006|accessdate=December 21, 2006}}{{cite news|title=Stadium Agreement With TCF Has Extra Perks|first=Rick|last=Moore|url=http://www1.umn.edu/umnnews/Feature_Stories/TCF_extra_benefits.html|work=UMNnews|publisher=Regents of the University of Minnesota|date=April 7, 2005|accessdate=October 21, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070613153716/http://www1.umn.edu/umnnews/Feature_Stories/TCF_extra_benefits.html|archivedate=June 13, 2007|df=mdy-all}} If unable to fulfill its contractual obligations, TCF Financial Corporation must propose an alternate name subject to the approval of the university.{{cite news |title=TCF Band Stadium Could Be Renamed|first=Jake|last=Grovum|url=http://www.mndaily.com/articles/2007/11/28/72164741|newspaper=[[Minnesota Daily]]|date=November 28, 2006|accessdate=December 8, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071130180945/http://www.mndaily.com/articles/2007/11/28/72164741|archivedate=November 30, 2007}} Other corporate donations have been pledged as well, including [[Best Buy]] ($3 million),{{cite news |title=Fundraising for Stadium On Track|first=Karlee|last=Weinmann|url=http://www.mndaily.com/articles/2006/10/12/69355|newspaper=[[Minnesota Daily]]|date=October 12, 2006|accessdate=October 12, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070105144402/http://www.mndaily.com/articles/2006/10/12/69355|archivedate=January 5, 2007}} [[Dairy Queen]] ($2.5 million),{{cite news |title=DQ to Help Fund TCF Stadium|first=Jake|last=Grovum|url=http://www.mndaily.com/articles/2007/11/14/72164515|newspaper=[[Minnesota Daily]]|date=November 14, 2006|accessdate=December 8, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071116060533/http://www.mndaily.com/articles/2007/11/14/72164515|archivedate=November 16, 2007}} [[Target Corporation]] ($2 million),{{cite news |title=Survey: Students Split Over Stadium, Predict Fee Increase|first=Bryce|last=Haugen|url=http://www.mndaily.com/articles/2007/03/09/71130|newspaper=Minnesota Daily|date=March 9, 2007|accessdate=March 9, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070311230412/http://www.mndaily.com/articles/2007/03/09/71130|archivedate=March 11, 2007}} Federated Insurance, [[General Mills]], and [[Norwest Equity Partners]].{{cite web|title=TCF Bank Stadium Groundbreaking|publisher=University of Minnesota|date=September 30, 2006|url=http://www.gophersports.com/video39/WRJURWHQNZQTVDO.20060930204004.wmv?DB_OEM_ID=8400|format=.wmv|accessdate=May 21, 2007}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{multiple image|footer=The Tribal Nations Plaza, named after the [[Mdewakanton|Shakopee Mdewakanton]]. Their donation of $14.5 million to the university was the largest gift in Gopher athletics history|width=225|image1=Plaza-Gopher stadium-20100914.JPG|alt1=Large sign saying "M", towering above a field of long grass|image2=Gopher stadium plaza.JPG}} The university also accepts donations from individuals. Initially donations were only being sought from "high-end" donors (those contributing $100,000 or more), but in June 2008 the university expanded the fundraising effort to gather smaller donations as well.{{cite news|title=New Gophers Stadium Starts Search for More Cash|url=http://www.kare11.com/news/news_article.aspx?storyid=513105|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120905193719/http://www.kare11.com/news/news_article.aspx?storyid=513105|dead-url=yes|archive-date=September 5, 2012|work=KARE11.com|date=June 3, 2008|accessdate=June 3, 2008}}{{cite web |title=How Can I Help?|publisher=University of Minnesota via Internet Archive|url=http://www1.umn.edu/stadium/help.php|accessdate=June 19, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071213204852/http://www1.umn.edu/stadium/help.php|archivedate=December 13, 2007}}{{cite news |title=U's Stadium Dream Runs Into Financial Reality|first=Mike|last=Kaszuba|url=http://www.startribune.com/gophers/story/1295440.html|newspaper=[[Star Tribune]]|location=Minneapolis|date=July 11, 2007|accessdate=July 11, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070713223410/http://www.startribune.com/gophers/story/1295440.html|archivedate=July 13, 2007}} On May 21, 2009, the University announced they had received a $6 million donation from [[T. Denny Sanford]], meaning the university had achieved its goal of $86 million in private fund raising.{{cite news |title=Sanford Pledges $6M to Gophers Football Stadium|url=http://www.lacrossetribune.com/articles/2009/05/21/sportsupdate/08gophers.txt|newspaper=[[La Crosse Tribune]]|date=May 21, 2009|accessdate=May 21, 2009}} The remainder of the university's portion will come from a $12.50 per semester student fee ($25 per year) and game day parking revenue. Even though the cost of building TCF Bank Stadium originated at $248.7 million, changes in the construction planning raised the cost to $288.5 million.{{cite web|title=Regents approve stadium design, new price tag|publisher=University of Minnesota|date=January 3, 2007|url=http://www1.umn.edu/umnnews/Feature_Stories/Regents_approve_stadium_design.html|accessdate=July 8, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070714024702/http://www1.umn.edu/umnnews/Feature_Stories/Regents_approve_stadium_design.html|archivedate=July 14, 2007|df=mdy-all}} The university has vowed that even if the stadium cost rises again, it will not seek more money from the state nor increase the student fees any further. The University has been charging all U of M students a mandatory stadium fee of $12.50 every semester since planning for the project began, and is continuing this fee despite the stadium being finished. The cost of the stadium was $288.5 million of which the university had to pay 52%, and with an average of more than 50,000 students in a given year, in one semester the university makes more than $625,000 from the stadium fee, meaning they receive more than $12.5 million every 10 years from students. ===Shakopee Mdewakanton Sioux donations=== The [[Shakopee-Mdewakanton Indian Reservation|Shakopee Mdewakanton Sioux Community]] (SMSC) agreed to donate $10 million for stadium construction, the largest gift Gopher athletics has ever received. The university matched an additional $2.5 million to create a $5 million endowment for scholarships for Native American and low-income students. The hospitality plaza on the stadium's west side and the scholarship were named to honor the community, and the plaza designed to "... celebrate the history, presence, and cultural contributions of all eleven Native American tribes in Minnesota".{{cite news |title=Shakopee Tribe's Gift Moves U Closer to Stadium Fundraising Goal|first=Art|last=Hughes|url=http://minnesota.publicradio.org/display/web/2007/10/19/stadmoney/|work=[[Minnesota Public Radio]]|date=October 19, 2007|accessdate=October 20, 2007}}{{cite press release|title=U of M receives $12.5 million gift from Shakopee Mdewakanton Sioux Community|url=http://www1.umn.edu/umnnews/news_details.php?release=071019_3591&page=NS|author=University News Service|publisher=Regents of the University of Minnesota|date=October 19, 2007|accessdate=October 21, 2007}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite web|title=U receives $12.5 million for stadium, scholarships|url=http://www1.umn.edu/umnnews/Feature_Stories/U_receives_2412.5_million_for_stadium2C_scholarshi.html|publisher=University of Minnesota|accessdate=October 19, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071214010045/http://www1.umn.edu/umnnews/Feature_Stories/U_receives_2412.5_million_for_stadium2C_scholarshi.html|archivedate=December 14, 2007|df=mdy-all}} The University received an additional $2 million from the SMSC for construction of the plaza in 2009.{{cite book|title=Donation Report|year=2009|publisher=Shakopee Mdewakanton Sioux Community}} ==Alcohol controversy== University president Robert Bruininks originally planned to have the school apply for a state liquor license in order to serve beer and wine in limited areas of the stadium. Under his proposal, alcohol would have been available only to occupants of premium [[season ticket]] seats ranging in price from $1,800 to $45,000 a year. This is/was consistent with the University's long-held alcohol policy at other on-campus athletic venues, such as Williams Arena and Mariucci Arena. This is also consistent with other NCAA institutions (including all other Big Ten Conference teams except for the University of Michigan and Ohio State University) with on-campus stadiums.{{cite news |title=U of M Wants to Sell Beer At Football Games, If You Can Afford It|first=Tim|last=Post|url=http://minnesota.publicradio.org/display/web/2008/11/12/u_of_m_wants_to_sell_beer_at_football_games_if_you_can_afford_it/|work=[[Minnesota Public Radio]]|date=November 13, 2008|accessdate=November 13, 2008}} No [[Big Ten Conference|Big Ten]] stadiums serve alcohol in their general seating. In May 2009, the state legislature passed a law that states that no alcohol may be served or sold anywhere in the stadium, including in suites and premium boxes, unless all ticketholders 21 or older in the stadium can buy alcohol at a game.{{cite web|url=https://www.revisor.leg.state.mn.us/laws/?id=120&doctype=chapter&year=2009&type=0|title=Minnesota Laws, 2009, Chapter 120, section 8|publisher=State of Minnesota|year=2009|accessdate=August 17, 2012}} The University of Minnesota regents voted on June 24, 2009, on Bruininks' subsequent proposal to ban alcohol entirely at campus athletic events (and also ban it in Mariucci and Williams arenas), which passed 10–2.{{cite news |title=No Booze for U Sports Fans|first=Alex|last=Ebert|url=http://www.startribune.com/local/49012236.html|publisher=Avista Capital Partners|newspaper=[[Star Tribune]]|location=Minneapolis|date=June 25, 2009|accessdate=June 25, 2009}} In May 2010, the legislature passed a law saying that alcohol could be served in premium seating if it was also available in one-third of the general seats. Bruininks declined to ask the board of regents to make this compromise. Dan Wolter, a spokesman for the university, said, "We recognize and understand that underage drinking is a big problem in our society as a whole so that is a stand that the University wanted to take."{{cite news |title=U of M Decides Not to Sell Alcohol in TCF Bank Football Stadium|first=Rupa|last=Shenoy|url=http://minnesota.publicradio.org/display/web/2010/06/07/no-alcohol-in-stadium/|work=[[Minnesota Public Radio]]|date=June 7, 2010|accessdate=June 7, 2010}} On July 11, 2012, the university regents voted to allow beer sales at the stadium starting in the fall of 2012.{{cite news |title=U of M regents approve beer at TCF Bank Stadium|url=http://www.southernminn.com/northfield_news/news/state/article_85007014-4305-5de7-ba26-fa64d222dca9.html|work=Northfield News|date=July 11, 2012|accessdate=July 12, 2012}} ==Attendance== {{col-start}} {{col-2}} ===Gophers football=== {| class=wikitable style="text-align:center" !
