style="background:#585958; color:#FFFFFF; border:2px solid #9BCDE4;| Average !! style="background:#585958; color:#FFFFFF; border:2px solid #9BCDE4;| Season highest |- |   [[2017 Minnesota United FC season|2017]]{{cite web|url=http://soccerstadiumdigest.com/2017-mls-attendance/|title=2017 MLS Attendance - Soccer Stadium Digest|author=|date=|website=soccerstadiumdigest.com}}  ||   349,138  || 17|| 20,538 || align=right|[[2017 Atlanta United FC season|Atlanta United FC]] (35,043) |- | [[2018 Minnesota United FC season|2018]]{{cite web|url=https://soccerstadiumdigest.com/2018-mls-attendance|title=2018 MLS Attendance - Soccer Stadium Digest|author=|date=|website=soccerstadiumdigest.com}}||   406,342  || 17|| 23,902 || align=right|[[2018 LA Galaxy season|Los Angeles Galaxy]] (52,242) {{col-end}} ==Other uses== ===Marching band/drum & bugle corps=== [[File:Pride of Minnesota.JPG|thumb|Pride of Minnesota]] The stadium replaced [[Northrop Auditorium]] as the home of the [[University of Minnesota Marching Band]], providing it with direct access to the stadium field and new storage, rehearsal, locker room, and office facilities. The stadium has been host to the DCI Minnesota{{cite web |title=World's Top Drum and Bugle Corps to Compete at TCF Bank Stadium|url=http://www1.umn.edu/news/news-releases/2010/UR_CONTENT_219520.html|publisher=University of Minnesota|date=July 17, 2010|accessdate=November 9, 2013}} [[Drum and bugle corps (modern)|Drum & Bugle Corps]] competition sponsored by [[Drum Corps International]] and hosted by [[Minnesota Brass]]. The first competition, held on July 18, 2010, was cancelled during the show due to the touchdown of a nearby tornado.{{cite web |title=Wild Weather Puts Damper on Inaugural DCI Minnesota Event|first=Darcy|last=Wallace|url=http://www.dci.org/news/view.cfm?news_id=8a5fcfac-f07e-4fac-83e6-b6b8a1c714d7|publisher=Drum Corps International|date=July 18, 2010|accessdate=November 9, 2013}} In 2011, the competition was won by the [[The Cavaliers Drum and Bugle Corps|Cavaliers]],{{cite web |title=Minneapolis, MN|url=http://www.dci.org/scores/recap/view.cfm?event_id=60576046-147b-4af0-a989-c54a0be0a819|publisher=Drum Corps International|date=July 16, 2011|accessdate=November 9, 2013}} and in 2012 was won by the [[Blue Devils Drum and Bugle Corps|Blue Devils]]. The stadium is currently home to the Drum Corps International Minnesota event, taking place in mid-July each year since 2010.{{cite book |last=University of Minnesota|title=University of Minnesota On-Campus Football Stadium - Final EIS|year=2003}} ===Other university activities=== [[File:IMAG0252.jpg|thumb|upright|South Wing of the Stadium featuring Goldy's Lockerroom]] The university also utilizes the stadium for [[intramural sports]], career fairs, graduation ceremonies,{{cite news |title=The U's New Stadium Is About More Than Football|first=Deborah|last=Hopp|url=http://blog.lib.umn.edu/stadium/stadium/2006/02/|newspaper=[[St. Paul Pioneer Press]]|date=February 28, 2006|accessdate=July 8, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070614164236/http://blog.lib.umn.edu/stadium/stadium/2006/02/|archivedate=June 14, 2007}} and other special events. ===Concerts=== {| class="wikitable" style=font-size:100% style="text-align:center" |- ! The [[Minnesota State High School League]]'s football championship games were played at the stadium in 2014 and 2015. ===Soccer=== [[File:MNUFCTCF.jpeg|thumb|Minnesota United FC playing at TCF Bank Stadium]] TCF Bank Stadium was evaluated as a potential venue for a [[United States 2018 and 2022 FIFA World Cup bid|bid by the United States]] to host the [[2018 and 2022 FIFA World Cup bids|2018 or 2022]] [[FIFA World Cup]].{{cite news |title=TCF Bank Stadium, Metrodome in Running to Host World Cup Soccer Games in 2018 or 2022|url=http://www.twincities.com/ci_12107921?IADID|newspaper=[[St. Paul Pioneer Press]]|date=April 9, 2009|accessdate=April 9, 2009}}{{cite news|title=USA Bid Committee Issues Requests For Proposals to 37 Potential FIFA World Cup Host Cities For 2018 or 2022 |work=[[US Soccer]] |date=June 16, 2009 |url=http://www.ussoccer.com/articles/viewArticle.jsp_14876672.html |accessdate=June 16, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090619071040/http://www.ussoccer.com/articles/viewArticle.jsp_14876672.html |archivedate=June 19, 2009 }}{{cite news|title=USA Bid Committee Announces List of 27 Cities Still in Contention For Inclusion in U.S. Bid to Host FIFA World Cup in 2018 or 2022 |work=[[US Soccer]] |date=August 20, 2009 |url=http://www.ussoccer.com/News/Federation-Services/2009/08/27-Cities-Chosen-For-World-Cup-Bid.aspx |accessdate=August 22, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090926202259/http://www.ussoccer.com/News/Federation-Services/2009/08/27-Cities-Chosen-For-World-Cup-Bid.aspx |archivedate=September 26, 2009 |df= }} In addition, TCF Bank Stadium was planned as a preliminary soccer venue in the [[Chicago bid for the 2016 Summer Olympics]]. On August 2, 2014, TCF Bank Stadium hosted a group B match as part of the [[International Champions Cup]] between [[Manchester City FC]] and [[Olympiacos]].{{cite web|url=http://internationalchampionscup.com/schedule/sch/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-06-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140625105358/http://internationalchampionscup.com/schedule/sch/ |archivedate=June 25, 2014 |df= }} The [[Ottawa Fury]] also played [[Minnesota United FC]] as part of a double-header. A temporary grass field was laid over the artificial surface for the games. The field was 120 yards by 68 yards. The University of Minnesota [[women's soccer]] team continues to play at [[Elizabeth Lyle Robbie Stadium]]. For [[Minnesota United FC |Minnesota United FC's]] first season in [[Major League Soccer]], the club played their home matches at TCF Bank Stadium as they await the opening of [[Allianz Field]] in St. Paul. The field for Minnesota United FC games are on {{convert|120|x|70|yd|m|abbr=on}}.{{cite web|last1=de los Rios|first1=Gabriel|last2=Calderon|first2=Rudy|title=All 22 MLS stadiums for the 2017 season|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2017/03/02/all-22-mls-stadiums-2017-season|publisher=Major League Soccer|accessdate=March 4, 2017}} ====International Soccer Matches==== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; width:95%;" style="text-align:center" |- !style="text-align:center; background: #7A0019; color: white; {{box-shadow border|a|#FFCC33|2px}};"|Date !style="text-align:center; background: #7A0019; color: white; {{box-shadow border|a|#FFCC33|2px}};"|Winning Team !style="text-align:center; background: #7A0019; color: white; {{box-shadow border|a|#FFCC33|2px}};"|Result !style="text-align:center; background: #7A0019; color: white; {{box-shadow border|a|#FFCC33|2px}};"|Losing Team !style="text-align:center; background: #7A0019; color: white; {{box-shadow border|a|#FFCC33|2px}};"|Tournament !style="text-align:center; background: #7A0019; color: white; {{box-shadow border|a|#FFCC33|2px}};"|Spectators |- |style="text-align:center;"|August 2, 2014 || {{flagicon|ENG}} [[Manchester City FC]] ||style="text-align:center;"|2–2 || {{flagicon|GRE}} [[Olympiacos]] ||style="text-align:center;"|[[2014 International Champions Cup]] ||style="text-align:center;"|34,047 |} ===Vikings=== [[File:TCF Bank Stadium Vikings.jpg|thumb|Minnesota Vikings colors on TCF Bank Stadium's field]] Due to [[Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome#2010 roof incident and replacement|a collapse of the Metrodome's roof]], the Minnesota Vikings' [[Monday Night Football]] game against the [[Chicago Bears]] was held at the stadium on December 20, [[2010 Minnesota Vikings season|2010]], which was the Vikings' first outdoor home game since exactly 29 years before when [[Metropolitan Stadium]] was closed.{{cite news |title = Vikings Will Play at TCF Bank Stadium|first=Seth|last=Kaplan|url=http://www.myfoxtwincities.com/dpp/sports/vikings/vikings/vikings-will-play-at-tcf-bank-stadium-dec-14-2010|work=[[KMSP-TV|KMSP]]|location=Minneapolis|date=December 14, 2010|accessdate=December 14, 2010}} The game ended with the Bears defeating the Vikings, 40−14.{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/2010122000/2010/REG15/bears@vikings |title=Bears 40 Vikings 14|publisher=National Football League|date=December 20, 2010|accessdate=August 17, 2012}} With the win, the Bears won the [[NFC North]] title and [[Devin Hester]] broke the kickoff return for touchdown record. This was [[Brett Favre]]'s last game in the [[National Football League|NFL]] after he sustained a concussion from being hit by [[Corey Wootton]].{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=5941067 |title=Brett Favre of Minnesota Vikings Leaves Game After Hard Hit|work=[[ESPN]]|date=December 21, 2010|accessdate=August 17, 2012}}{{cite web|last=Siddons|first=Larry|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-03/brett-favre-says-he-played-his-last-game-after-watching-vikings-loss.html|title=Brett Favre Says He Played His Last Game After Watching Vikings' Loss|work=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=January 3, 2011|accessdate=August 17, 2012}} The Vikings played the [[2014 Minnesota Vikings season|2014]] and [[2015 Minnesota Vikings season|2015 NFL seasons]] at the stadium during construction of [[U.S. Bank Stadium]], which required the demolition of the Metrodome. TCF Bank Stadium was the [[List of current National Football League stadiums|smallest stadium in the NFL by seat capacity]] for those two seasons. The Vikings reportedly paid $2 million for upkeep costs for those seasons.{{cite web |title=Vikings Strike Tentative Deal to Play at TCF Bank Stadium|first=Mike|last=Florio|url=http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2012/02/21/vikings-strike-tentative-deal-to-play-at-tcf-bank-stadium/|work=[[NBC Sports]]|date=February 21, 2012|accessdate=August 17, 2012}} The Vikings also spent $4.5 million to upgrade the facilities to NFL standards, mainly to include heating coils under the turf.{{cite news |title=Mortenson to Upgrade TCF Bank Stadium for Vikings|first=John|last=Vomhof Jr.|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/twincities/blog/sports-business/2013/07/mortenson-upgrade-tcf-bank-stadium.html|newspaper=[[American City Business Journals|Minneapolis/St. Paul Business Journal]]|date=July 10, 2013|accessdate=October 27, 2013}} The Vikings used the north sideline (opposite the press box) in 2014-15. ===Ice hockey=== The stadium hosted an outdoor NCAA hockey game between the [[Minnesota Golden Gophers men's ice hockey|Minnesota Golden Gophers]] and [[Ohio State Buckeyes men's ice hockey|Ohio State Buckeyes]] on January 17, 2014. The Gophers won 1-0 with 45,021 fans in attendance.{{cite web|url=http://www.foxsports.com/north/story/minnesota-enjoys-memorable-hockey-city-classic-win-over-ohio-state-011714|title=Minnesota enjoys memorable Hockey City Classic win over Ohio State - FOX Sports|date=January 18, 2014|publisher=}} It also hosted to its first [[National Hockey League|NHL]] contest on February 21, 2016 between the [[Minnesota Wild]] and the [[Chicago Blackhawks]] as part of the [[2016 NHL Stadium Series]]. The Wild won 6–1 in front of 50,426 fans. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I FBS football stadiums]] ==Notes and references== {{reflist|33em}} ==External links== * [http://www.gophersports.com/facilities/tcf-bank-stadium.html TCF Bank Stadium webpage] {{s-start-collapsible|header={{s-sta|et}}}} {{succession box | title = Home of the
[[Minnesota Golden Gophers football|Minnesota Golden Gophers]] | years = 2009–present | before = [[Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome]] | after = Current Stadium }} {{succession box | title = Home of the
[[Minnesota Vikings]] | years = 2014–2015 | before = [[Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome]] | after = [[U.S. Bank Stadium]] }} {{s-end}} {{Minnesota Golden Gophers football navbox}} {{University of Minnesota campus}} {{Big Ten Conference football venue navbox}} {{Minnesota Vikings}} {{Minnesota United FC}} {{Minnesota college football venues}} {{MLS Stadiums}} {{Minneapolis skyscrapers}} {{Defunct NFL stadiums}} {{Music venues of Minnesota}} {{good article}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tcf Bank Stadium}} [[Category:American football venues in Minnesota]] [[Category:Minnesota Golden Gophers football venues]] [[Category:Minnesota Vikings stadiums]] [[Category:Defunct National Football League venues]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2009]] [[Category:Sports venues in Minneapolis]] [[Category:2009 establishments in Minnesota]] [[Category:Ice hockey venues in Minneapolis]] [[Category:Outdoor ice hockey venues in the United States]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Minnesota]] [[Category:Minnesota United FC sports facilities]]

{{about|the ice hockey tabletop simulation game equipment similar to foosball|other table hockey|table hockey (disambiguation)}} {{refimprove|date=November 2008}} [[Image:Table hockey playing.JPG|thumb|right|150px|A [[Stiga]] table hockey game]] A '''table hockey game''', also called '''rod hockey game''', '''stick hockey''', '''bubble hockey''', and '''board hockey''', is a game for two players, derived from [[ice hockey]]. The game consists of a representation of a hockey rink; the players score goals by hitting a small puck into the opposing "net" with cutout figures that represent hockey players. The figures are manipulated by rods below the "ice": each one slides forward and back along its own narrow slot when the player pushes or pulls on the rod, or rotates (about a vertical axis) to shoot or [[stickhandle]] the puck when the player spins the rod. Though similar in concept to [[air hockey]] (commonly known as "glide hockey"), table hockey games are more of a simulation of the sport of ice hockey while air hockey is more abstract.
==Original table hockey== The game of table hockey was invented in 1932, by the Canadian Donald H. Munro Sr., in Toronto. Don, like so many Canadians in the depths of [[The Great Depression|the depression]], was short of cash for Christmas presents. He had a wife and three young children. That year, the family all pitched in and made the first table hockey game. This mechanical game was built out of scrap wood and metal, and included used coat hanger wire, butcher's twine, clock springs, and lumber from the [[coal bin]]. Unlike current games, the game looked more like an early pinball game, with one key difference: this was a two player game. The playing surface had a peak in the middle and sloped down toward each end. The players controlled levers for the goalie and flippers for the players.<ref name=AmericanRestoration>{{cite episode |title= Slap-shots and Stogies |series= American Restoration |airdate= 2014 }}</ref> The story goes that a travelling salesman noticed the game and encouraged Don to take the game down to the local Eaton's department store. Don did just that. The first game went in on a consignment deal. By the time Mr. Munro got home, the game was sold and more orders were placed.
== Manufacturers ==
There are many types of the game. The defunct [[Munro Games]] of Toronto, Ontario, Canada, manufactured the original variant of the game in Burlington, Ontario.<ref name=AmericanRestoration/> [[Stiga]] Games in [[Sweden]] are used in the [[ITHF table hockey|table hockey sport]] administered by the [[International Table Hockey Federation]].
The game has also been played using a variety of commercial boards in North America since the 1920s. Rick Benej,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dailyfreeman.com/article/DF/20101226/NEWS/312269984|title=FISCHLER: Charting popularity of Table Hockey|website=www.dailyfreeman.com|access-date=2016-04-18}}</ref> of [[Greenwich (town), New York|Greenwich, NY,]] has built table hockey games since the 1980s. His model has gone through three different designs and refinements over the years. The most popular board for many years was manufactured by the now-defunct [[Coleco]] company, and most North American boards (such as those built by The Carrom Company and Irwin toys) are a variant of this model. However, the Stiga board has begun to tap the North American market, even as other new boards continue to be introduced.
== Arcade version ==
The [[penny arcade (venue)|arcade]] version is called '[http://www.gameroomchamp.com/dome-hockey dome hockey]' or 'bubble hockey', because of the large plastic dome that covers the playing surface in order to prevent the puck either becoming lost or stolen. The most popular of these 'bubble hockey' tables is Chexx (USA vs. Soviet Union) and its successor, [[Super Chexx]] (Canada vs. USA).
== Game variations == [[Image:Dotoho weiß 525.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Do-To-Ho]] Another table hockey game, called Do-To-Ho, is completely different from the other games specified here. The play figures are not fastened to bars, but are mobile on the whole playing field. In their bases, just like in the puck, there is a ball bearing, so they slide like ice skate runners over the board. Moving a play figure is done via a short, unique knock against the figure with a small stick as in billiards. The play courses take place alternating, there are 'attack courses', with which the puck may be played by a play figure, and 'position courses' (defense courses as well as offside release courses), with which a play figure only may change position without touching the puck. Puck possession changes, if the aggressor misses the puck or hits an opposing play figure. Do-To-Ho was developed in Germany and published in 1994.
[[Image:MN Governor Residence hockey table 2007.JPG|thumb|Basement of [[Minnesota Governor's Residence]].]]

[[File:Ulama 37 (Aguilar).jpg|right|230px|thumb|[[Sinaloan]] ulama player in action.]] '''Ulama''' ({{IPA-es|uˈlama|}}) is a ball game played in a few communities in the [[Mexican state]] of [[Sinaloa]]. Descended from the [[Aztec]] version of the [[Mesoamerican ballgame]],<ref>Leyenaar (2001) p. 123.</ref> the game is one of the oldest continuously played sports in the world and is notable for the fact that it is the oldest known game using a rubber [[ball]].
==History== {{Main|Mesoamerican ballgame}} The word ''ulama'' comes from the [[Nahuatl]] word ''ōllamaliztli'' {{IPA-nah|oːlːamaˈlistɬi|}} a combination of ''ōllamas'' {{IPA-nah|ˈoːlːama|}} (playing of a game with a ball) and ''ōllei'' {{IPA-nah|ˈoːlːi|}} (rubber). ''Ōllamaliztli'' was the Aztec name for the Mesoamerican ballgame, whose roots extended back to at least the 2nd millennium [[Before Christ|BC]] and evidence of which has been found in nearly all [[Mesoamerica]]n cultures in an area extending from modern-day [[Mexico]] to [[El Salvador]], and possibly in modern-day [[Arizona]] and [[New Mexico]].<ref name="FOX">Fox, John. [https://books.google.com/books?id=LD6h3NHeHxgC&printsec=frontcover ''The ball : discovering the object of the game''], 1st ed., New York : Harper, 2012. {{ISBN|978-0-06-188179-4}}. Cf. Chapter 4: "Sudden Death in the New World" about the Ulama game.</ref> Archaeologists have uncovered rubber balls dating to at least 1600 BC,<ref>See [[El Manati]] article for information on recovery of the earliest rubber balls.</ref> ballgamer figures from at least 1200 BC, and nearly 1500 ancient ball courts.<ref name="FOX"/><ref>Taladoire counts 1560 courts discovered as of the year 2000, p. 98.</ref>
However, due to its religious and ritual aspects, [[Spain|Spanish]] [[Roman Catholicism|Catholics]] suppressed the game soon after the [[Spanish conquest of the Aztec Empire|Spanish conquest]], leaving it to survive in areas such as [[Sinaloa]], where Spanish influence was less pervasive.<ref>Leyenaar (2001) p. 128.</ref>
==Ulama== Ulama games are played on a temporary court called a ''tastei'' ({{IPA-all|tas.te|}}, from ''tlachtli'' {{IPA-nah|ˈt͡ɬat͡ʃt͡ɬi|}}, the Nahuatl word meaning "ballcourt"). The bounds of these long narrow courts are made by drawing or [[chalk]]ing thick lines in the dirt. The courts are divided into opposing sides by a center line, called an ''analco''. A ball that is allowed to cross the end line, the ''chichi'' or ''chivo'', will result in a point for the opposing team. Points or ''rayas'' ("lines", so named for the [[tally marks]] used to keep score) are gained in play. The scoring system provides for resetting the score to zero in certain conditions, which can make for lengthy games.
The modern-day game has three main forms:
*''Ulama de cadera'' or hip ulama. A hip ulama team consists of five or more players (but there could be as many as twelve) wearing loincloths, with leather hip pads for some protection against the heavy (3 kg, around 7 lb) rubber ball. *''Ulama de antebrazo'' or forearm ulama. Played on a smaller field, with teams of one to three players and a ball lighter than that of hip ulama, the games requires the players to return the ball using their wrapped forearm.<ref>For a more indepth look at hip ulama and forearm ulama, see Leyenaar (2001).</ref> Women often play this game. *''Ulama de mazo'' or ''Ulama de palo'', in which a heavy (6–7 kg or 13-15 lb) two-handed wooden paddle strikes a 500 g (1 lb) ball, usually with teams of three or four.<ref>Federación Mexicana de Juegos y Deportes Autóctonos y Tradicionales, A.C.</ref>
The object of the game is to keep the ball in play and in bounds. Depending on the score — and the local variant of the rules — the ball is played either high or low. A team scores a point when a player of the opposing team hits the ball out of turn; misses the ball; knocks the ball out of bounds; touches the ball with their hands or some other body part aside from the hip; accidentally touches a teammate; lets the ball stop moving before it reaches the centre line or even if they fail to announce the score after they have scored a point.
The first team that scores eight points wins. If both teams end up having the same number of points after a turn, both sides begin again from zero. One record-setting game reportedly lasted for eight days,{{citation needed|date=September 2013}} but most modern games are stopped after about two hours.
[[Image:Ullamaliztliwiditz.jpg|right|300px|thumb| Aztec ''ullamaliztli'' players performing for Charles V in Spain, drawn by Christoph Weiditz in 1528. Note the similarity in dress to the modern-day ''ulama'' player above.]]
==Ulama balls== ''See also [[Mesoamerican rubber balls]]''

Leiden. * {{cite book |author=Leyenaar, Ted |year=2001|chapter="The Modern Ballgames of Sinaloa: a Survival of the Aztec Ullamaliztli" |pages=97–115|title=The Sport of Life and Death: The Mesoamerican Ballgame |editor=E. Michael Whittington (Ed.) |publisher=Thames & Hudson |location=New York |isbn=0-500-05108-9}} * {{cite book |author=Taladoire, Eric|year=2001 |chapter=The Architectural Background of the Pre-Hispanic Ballgame |title=The Sport of Life and Death: The Mesoamerican Ballgame |editor=E. {{ Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Volkswagen Halle Braunschweig | image = [[File:Volkswagen_Halle_Braunschweig_Logo.svg|200px]]
[[File:VW_Halle_Braunschweig.jpg|250px]] | location = Europaplatz 1
38100 [[Braunschweig]], [[Niedersachsen]], [[Germany]] | built = September 20, 1999 | opened = September 20, 2000 | owner= Stadthalle Braunschweig Betriebsgesellschaft mbH | operator = | architect = KSP Engel und Zimmermann , Braunschweig | tenants= [[Basketball Löwen Braunschweig]] (2000–present) | seating_capacity= 6,600 (Basketball)
7,000 (Arena events)
8,000 (Concerts) }} '''Volkswagen Halle''' is an [[indoor arena|indoor sporting arena]] located in [[Braunschweig]], [[Germany]]. The capacity of the arena is 8,000 people.[http://www.volkswagenhalle.de/index.php?id=103 Kapazitäten] (in German). Accessed 22 March, 2013. It is currently home to the [[Basketball Löwen Braunschweig]] [[basketball]] team.[http://www.beko-bbl.de/remotecontent/deliver.php?menuid=1212&saisonx=2012&team_id=422&topmenu=270&xget=%2Fbeko-bbl%2Fteams%2Fteam-info.php Beko BBL - Klub-Informationen - New Yorker Phantoms Braunschweig] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130316030532/http://www.beko-bbl.de/remotecontent/deliver.php?menuid=1212&saisonx=2012&team_id=422&topmenu=270&xget=%2Fbeko-bbl%2Fteams%2Fteam-info.php |date=2013-03-16 }} (in German). Accessed 22 March, 2013. ==Sports== [[File:Braunschweig, Volkswagenhalle (2).jpg|thumb|180px|Volkswagen Halle in 2005.]] Aside from serving as the home venue of the Basketball Löwen (formerly New Yorker Phantoms) [[Basketball Bundesliga]] team, several other sporting events have been hosted in the arena. Those include four editions (2001–2003 and 2005) of the ''[[:de:Basketball-Supercup|BEKO Supercup]]'', an annual international basketball [[Exhibition game|exhibition tournament]] organized by the [[German Basketball Federation]],{{cite web|url=http://www.basketball-bund.de/teams/a-herren/geschichte/supercup-beko-supercup | language = German | title = Supercup-Geschichte | accessdate = 30 March 2013}} the annual international [[Equestrianism|equestrian]] tournament ''Löwen Classics'', three editions (2003–2005) of the [[Handball-Bundesliga]] [[:de:HBL All-Star Game|All-Star Game]] as well as the annual pre-season-tournament ''Handball-Bundesliga-Cup'', [[tennis]] [[Davis Cup]] matches ([[2001 Davis Cup World Group|2001]] and [[2008 Davis Cup World Group|2008]]), [[indoor soccer]] tournaments and [[boxing]]. In October 2007, [[World Wrestling Entertainment]] hosted an event as part of the ''[[WWE Raw]] [[Survivor Series]] Tour'' at the arena.{{cite web|url=http://www.bsww.de/archiv03/wwegermany/braunschweig_oktober2007.shtml| language = German | title = RAW Survivor Series Tour | accessdate = 30 March 2013}} ==Other uses== The arena also serves as a [[concert]] venue. Artists that have performed at the Volkswagen Halle include [[a-ha]], [[Alice Cooper]], [[Deep Purple]], [[Die Ärzte]], [[Die Fantastischen Vier]], [[Dio (band)|Dio]], [[Bob Dylan]],{{cite web|url=https://www.bobdylan.com/de/events/location/Braunschweig,%20Germany| title = Set lists: Braunschweig, Germany | publisher =bobdylan.com| accessdate = 19 October 2015}} [[David Garrett (musician)|David Garrett]],{{cite web|url=http://www.braunschweiger-zeitung.de/kultur/buehne/article208741867/David-Garrett-in-der-VW-Halle-Teil-1.html| title = David Garrett in der VW-Halle | publisher =[[Braunschweiger Zeitung]]| language = German| accessdate = 18 November 2016}} [[Nena]], [[Ozzy Osbourne]], and [[Status Quo (band)|Status Quo]]. From 2001 to 2009,{{cite web|url=http://www.braunbattleoftheyear.com/about.html|title=About BOTY|accessdate=27 August 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628oflRIh?url=http://www.braunbattleoftheyear.com/about.html|archivedate=2 October 2011|df=}} and again since 2013,{{cite web|url=http://www.braunbattleoftheyear.com/final-2013/program/the-grand-final.html | title = BOTY WORLD FINALS RETURN TO GERMANY IN 2013 | accessdate = 30 March 2013}} the annual finals of the international [[B-boying|breakdance]] competition [[Battle of the Year]] have been held at the Volkswagen Halle. ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == {{Commonscat|Volkswagenhalle Braunschweig}} * {{Official website|http://www.volkswagenhalle.de/}} {{Coord|52|15|27|N|10|31|09|E|display=title|region:DE-NI_type:landmark_source:dewiki}} [[Category:Indoor arenas in Germany]] [[Category:Basketball Löwen Braunschweig]] [[Category:Sport in Braunschweig]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Braunschweig]] [[Category:Sports venues in Lower Saxony]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Germany]] [[Category:Handball venues in Germany]] [[Category:Tennis venues in Germany]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2000]] [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 2000]]
